title: Tower Of Black Winds
opening: A group of thieves led by a disowned son of House Gautier has stolen a Hero's Relic and begun to run amok. Seeking to neutralize this threat, the church is sending your house there to settle the matter.

intro.speaker: Edelgard
intro.line: This weather is unfortunate. Those villagers were right when they said a storm was brewing. But they were more afraid of an attack than they were of the storm. Let's end this quickly.

intro.speaker: Hubert
intro.line: The thieves have taken Conand Tower as their base... There it is in the distance.

intro.speaker: Edelgard
intro.line: Miklan must be more skilled than your average thief to have overtaken a place like that.

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: This area was the site of a massive battle several hundred years ago. That's when invasions from the north were at their peak. Back then, this tower was built for both surveillance and defense. It will be difficult to seize it.

intro.speaker: Edelgard
intro.line: You know your history, Gilbert. If I recall correctly, you're from the Kingdom aren't you?

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: I left my home long ago. If you have any questions about the mission, I'd be happy to answer them.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: What do you know about House Gautier?

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: What do you know about the leader of the thieves?

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: House Gautier has always placed great importance on whether or not someone bears a Crest. Margrave Gautier has two sons. A Crest never manifested for his eldest. It's not hard to imagine why he left and wound up in this sort of life.

intro.speaker: Edelgard
intro.line: There's no reason that Crests should have the power to dictate someone's destiny. Don't you agree, Gilbert? He was just another victim of cruel fate. Forsaken by the goddess, who now demands his execution.

intro.speaker: Dimitri
intro.line: It should be in our sights soon, Professor. The abandoned tower those thieves are using as a base... Conand Tower.

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: This area was the site of a massive battle several hundred years ago. That's when invasions from the north were at their peak. Back then, this tower was built for both surveillance and defense. It will be difficult to seize it.

intro.speaker: Dimitri
intro.line: You're very well informed, Gilbert. Please, tell us more.

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: Well, I... Ah. You're joking.

intro.speaker: Dimitri
intro.line: Professor. Did you see the local villages? They were in rough shape, no doubt because of the thief attacks. They're not going to make it through the winter in that condition. If the thieves had taken up pillaging in order to survive, that would be deplorable...but understandable. But this... This is something else entirely. It looks as though they destroyed those villages purely for pleasure. No matter what their reasons may be, that sort of behavior cannot be allowed. Ever.

intro.speaker: Sylvain
intro.line: Don't bother losing your head over those lowlifes, Your Highness. It's wasted effort.

intro.speaker: Dimitri
intro.line: Sylvain... The thieves' leader...the one who stole the Relic. Word has it he's your older brother. I know he's been disowned, but...

intro.speaker: Sylvain
intro.line: He is no longer a member of House Gautier...or my brother. He's nothing more than a common thief.

intro.speaker: Dimitri
intro.line: Are you sure about that? It would be understandable to find this situation...well, regrettable, to say the least.

intro.speaker: Sylvain
intro.line: Regrets? Heh, you must be joking. You know we're far past the point of regret. And it always falls on the younger brother to clean up the mistakes of their elders, doesn't it?

intro.speaker: Dimitri
intro.line: This rain threatens a coming storm. We must hurry and begin our war council before the heavens let loose.

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: Say, Teach. This must be the tower, don't you think? Even for a tower, it's pretty.. er, towering.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: It's more like a fortress.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: It would prove difficult to attack.

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: It's a remnant of ancient wars... These thieves certainly found themselves a great place to nest. I hear their leader, Miklan, is a former noble. It makes sense he would already know about this place.

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: Several hundred years ago, this was an important stronghold for diffusing invasions from the north. Back then, this tower was built for both surveillance and defense. It will be difficult to seize it.

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: Gilbert, isn't it? You hail from the Kingdom, right? No wonder you're so knowledgeable. While we're chatting so amicably... Do you mind if I ask some questions?

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: I don't mind. If I can answer them, I will.

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: Have you ever seen the Lance of Ruin?

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: I have. A long time ago. It was an impressive, if not eerily ominous, weapon to behold. According to Margrave Gautier, Miklan has used the lance to turn the tables on his pursuers.

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: Is that right? Then those without a Crest can use it as well... Interesting. As far as I knew, that wasn't possible. And then we have the mythical Sword of the Creator, which can't be used by anyone except Teach, Crest or no Crest. Maybe you're just that special, Teach. Or maybe there's something you're not telling us. Either way, I expect big things from you in this battle.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: Leave it to me.

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: Ha! I love a good show of confidence. I'll do my best too. You can count on it.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: I'm relying on you, Claude.

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: Are you now? Then why don't you hand over the Sword of the Creator for a bit? Then again, it would just be a heavy blade in my hands. There's no justice in this world, Teach.

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: Ugh, the rain is really coming down now. Let's finish this quickly.

conversation.speaker: Sothis
conversation.line: A stone? A stone... I do not understand. Yet as I think of it, the pounding in my chest grows faster still. But is that me...or is it you? Hmm...

conversation.speaker: Edelgard
conversation.line: For a Hero's Relic to be stolen... It's unheard of.

conversation.speaker: Hubert
conversation.line: And just last month, the Sword of the Creator was almost stolen too.

conversation.speaker: Edelgard
conversation.line: Also quite unheard of. What imprudence.

conversation.speaker: Hubert
conversation.line: For House Gautier to invite us on to their land, they must be desperate. But at least we'll have the stalwart knights ready to stand around and watch us do all the work.

conversation.speaker: Dimitri
conversation.line: Say, I hear that a Knight of Seiros named Gilbert will be joining us for our mission this moon. He is skilled, which is surely a boon for us. Still... That was not very thoughtful of Lady Rhea.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Do you know him?

conversation.speaker: Dimitri
conversation.line: Ahh, well... No, I do not. Not really. All I will say is that we have trained together a few times in the past.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Do you have history with him?

conversation.speaker: Dimitri
conversation.line: No... It's nothing. In any case, you should at least introduce yourself to him before we depart.

conversation.speaker: Dimitri
conversation.line: House Gautier is Sylvain's home. It would be nice if you could check on him as well.

conversation.speaker: Dimitri
conversation.line: I am sorry that the Kingdom's unrest did not stop with Lord Lonato... Professor... The Heroes' Relics are incredibly powerful. Please be on your guard.

conversation.speaker: Claude
conversation.line: Oof. This wasn't the first time I've taken part in an Alliance roundtable conference, but it was still exhausting. There's not enough cooperation in that group, especially from Lorenz's father. But at least my grandfather was surprisingly alert. Judging by that, I'd say he's got at least five more years in him.

conversation.speaker: Claude
conversation.line: Hey, Teach. I hear you were able to use the Sword of the Creator. That means... What does that mean? Could it mean that you're a descendant of Nemesis, the King of Liberation?!

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: The coffin of Seiros in the Holy Mausoleum should have held her remains. Instead, they say, it held the Sword of the Creator. What could it mean?

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: Swinging a sword about in the Holy Mausoleum? The potential for damage is too great to imagine. I sincerely hope the saints' coffins were not damaged.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: They didn't.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: One might've been scratched.

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: Were you using magic? I've heard you weren't, but– Ugh! It's torture not being able to go inside the Holy Mausoleum for an entire year.

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: You and your class were at that fight in the Holy Mausoleum, right? I sincerely hope the holy artifacts are unscathed. I admit I wish I could've been there to see it all, even if it does make me queasy. But I was there too early. I'd gone first thing in the morning. At noon, one of the monks chased me out saying I'd been there too long. Who were they to decide when I've been somewhere too long?

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: I heard a relic was stolen. If this had something to do with a family conflict, I don't think I could choose a side.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Even if there's a clear guilty party?

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: I think I'd be a pretty good judge of that!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: We can't allow a Hero's Relic to be stolen.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: What if it's some kind of powerful weapon? I want one too!

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: I know Relics aren't easy to come by, but I'd still like to get my hands on one...

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: I'm gonna keep training until I can beat you!

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: I'm not secretly eating cake!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I can sense it.

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: Hmm... OK, what's Bernie doing right now? Oh, fine. You got me. But keep it a secret, all right?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I'll take your word for it.

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: You're getting pretty good at talking through the door, Professor!

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: So, you have a Crest too, eh, Professor? Does that mean you're descended from nobility? You've certainly got the look for it... I sure do wish there were more nobles like you, Professor. A teacher, a mercenary, and so very mysterious... How could a girl ever get enough?

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: I have never had goings to the Kingdom's north. I hear the people of north are cold and have much loneliness. Professor, I hear you have had work...have worked as a mercenary in the Kingdom. Did you find joy in this? You cannot remember? Is that having possibility? I have amazement...

conversation.speaker: Dedue
conversation.line: I know Lord Rodrigue. He paid repeated visits to His Highness after the previous king was killed.

conversation.speaker: Dedue
conversation.line: The Western Church. The Central Church. They believe in the same goddess, but oppose one another. Fódlan is a complicated place.

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: Have you seen a man who looks like me? He's middle-aged and relatively tall.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I have.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I have not.

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: If you get the chance, tell him I've gone out. OK?

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: Think of it! The Sword of the Creator, belonging to the ancient King Nemesis. You have to master it as soon as you can. I can't wait to face off against such a legendary weapon!

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: So the whole plan to attack the monastery was some plot devised by the Western Church? That means they used Lonato. What right do they have to drag a good man like that into their schemes?!

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: There's going to be a big investigation into the Western Church soon. I wish I could be a part of it. I want to hear for myself why Lonato had to die.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: I'm so sorry my older brother is causing you all this hassle, Professor. Don't misunderstand, I always thought he was a piece of garbage, but I never thought he'd steal the Relic. I can't wait to see his face when he realizes I'm in the group that was sent to take him down.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: I can't believe my own brother is the leader of the bandits. House Gautier is my true home…and his. Please, Professor. He really is one of the worst people I've ever known, but we still… We share the same blood. We're still family.

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: Isn't it strange? Saint Seiros's body was missing from her coffin, but they found a sword in its place... Do you think she moved from her coffin and left the sword behind?

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: Professor! You looked like a natural wielding the Sword of the Creator! It's strange though, isn't it? The last owner of the sword was Nemesis, but I thought he didn't have any descendants…

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: Hey, Professor? Did you happen to see that man I was looking for earlier? I just spotted him by the dining hall, but then he ran away!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Who is he to you?

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: He... To be honest, he's my father. He's using a different name now, but there's no mistaking it. It's him. I know it is!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I might have seen him.

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: Oh? You saw him by the entrance to the monastery? Thank you, Professor!

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: Father... I've found you at last!

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: Professor! If you're heading to the Kingdom, I would recommend taking a coat. It's chilly, even at this time of year. It also rains a fair bit. Don't get caught out there without protection, or you're sure to catch a cold!

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: Wow, Lord Rodrigue in the flesh... What is Felix doing? This is such a rare opportunity for him to see his family...

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: Professor, please leave Sylvain alone for the time being. The thing is, the bandits' leader who stole the Relic...is Sylvain's disinherited older brother.

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: I have heard that someone from House Gautier, one of the Kingdom of Faerghus's noble families, is causing some sort of commotion. What a complete disgrace to the nobility.

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: Hey, Professor. Don't you think everyone's making too big a fuss over these Crests or Heroes' Relics or whatever they're called? How important can that stuff really be?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It's very important.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I'm not sure.

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: Personally, I don't even care that I don't have a Crest. I'll take muscles over Crests any day. Heck, I'll take muscles over a hot meal! Actually...

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: Don't you think Professor Hanneman's been acting a bit...strange? Maybe he's made some kind of big discovery.

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: Is it true that Lady Rhea entrusted the Sword of the Creator to you? I can hardly even fathom you being capable of wielding something of such power. Just who are you, anyway?

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: Aristocrats are fools–-allowing their lives to be dictated by their Crests. Though...I suppose I am much the same in that regard...

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: Some people are unhappy because they don't have the Crest they want... And some are unhappy because they have a Crest they never asked for.

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: I thought school life would be peaceful and quiet, with a sprinkle of drama to keep things interesting. But since you arrived, it's been one thing after another. Is that just a coincidence, I wonder?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I believe so.

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: Oh, I was just kidding! Anyway, as I said before, I do like having a little drama in my life.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Maybe. Maybe not.

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: What do you mean? I don't like the way you said that. Stop trying to spook me!

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: Captain Jeralt was all furrowed brow earlier. Do you know what's got him so concerned? If there's a problem, I want to help any way I can.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I don't know.

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: OK. I doubt there's anything I can do for him, but I figured I'd ask anyway.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Why don't you ask him yourself?

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: I did, but he just dodged the question. Still, it's worrying to see him like that.

conversation.speaker: Rhea
conversation.line: You must be rather bewildered by the power that was hidden within. However, know that I believe in you. I have no doubt that you will use that power justly. You will most certainly fulfill the grand destiny that the goddess has seen fit to grant you.

conversation.speaker: Seteth
conversation.line: Ah, Professor. Jeralt was looking for you.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Where is he?

conversation.speaker: Seteth
conversation.line: It seems he has gone off somewhere. If he is not in his room, then surely someone has seen him. Ask around.

conversation.speaker: Seteth
conversation.line: How are you managing the Sword of the Creator? No problems? I hope you have not left it lying somewhere unattended or anything foolish like that.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: No problems.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I'm not quite used to it yet.

conversation.speaker: Seteth
conversation.line: You will need the sword's power on your next mission. I trust you will handle it without much issue.

conversation.speaker: Flayn
conversation.line: Why is that fish so...still? Wait-–is it swimming sideways?! Perhaps... Perhaps it is resigned to its woeful fate of being plucked from the water and eaten... Ah, Professor. You are so outgoing with all of the students. I would like to have more opportunities to connect with you, though I am certain my brother would disapprove.

conversation.speaker: Catherine
conversation.line: You acquitted yourself honorably last month. To think they'd go into the Holy Mausoleum and assault the Goddess Tower... I cannot imagine the Western Church is acting on its own. Someone must have been helping them. As for the masked knight who escaped, his days are numbered. I hope we find him soon, so I can kill him myself.

conversation.speaker: Gilbert
conversation.line: Hail, Professor. If I may introduce myself, I am Gilbert. My life has been spent as a dedicated knight. I am to accompany you on your assignment. I may have slowed a step in recent years, but I pledge to you the full extent of my abilities.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Aren't you too formal?

conversation.speaker: Gilbert
conversation.line: I beg your pardon, but such is my nature.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It's a pleasure to meet you.

conversation.speaker: Gilbert
conversation.line: No, Professor. The pleasure is all mine, I assure you.

conversation.speaker: Jeritza
conversation.line: Mercedes... Her face looks...familiar...

conversation.speaker: Hanneman
conversation.line: Oh my...the Crest of Flames? Could it really... Yes, the actual Crest of Flames! No, that is quite enough. I should compose myself. I must remain objective in my research. Objective. Professional.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Excitement is understandable.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I respect your self control.

conversation.speaker: Hanneman
conversation.line: The scandal with the Western Church troubles me. We cannot afford to let ourselves be swept along, and yet...

conversation.speaker: Manuela
conversation.line: It's awful, just awful what happened with the Rite of Rebirth. The infirmary... Well, it was a mess. Things are finally calm again, and so I've come here to unwind. Let me tell you, I put all of my knowledge to use keeping those kids alive. Still, the truth of it is that when someone faces death for the first time...well, they figure out who they are. They learn if they can do it again. We can't lose them, Professor. Not to battle, or to cowardice. If you can keep them going, then I will too.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I will protect them.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I will try my best.

conversation.speaker: Tomas
conversation.line: The head of the Western Church holds the title of bishop. That's not as distinguished as an archbishop such as Lady Rhea, but it still comes with a fair amount of authority. If someone in that position plotted an assassin, I cannot help but think it must have been instigated by some outside force. There are bishops in the Eastern Church as well, but to speak frankly, they do not have much impact. They are under the influence of both the archbishop and the Leicester Alliance, so their ability to voice grievances is quite limited.

conversation.speaker: Cyril
conversation.line: I hear about the things you did. I'm so glad Lady Rhea's safe. I figure you're a great person after all, Professor.

conversation.speaker: Anna
conversation.line: I've been hearing a lot about you lately. Word on the street is you wield some amazing sword. If you ever want to sell it to me, I'd pay top G! Just kidding. Sorta. It's, uh, not for sale, is it?

conversation.speaker: Rodrigue
conversation.line: Professor. Have you seen my son, perchance? I have need of him.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: He went out.

conversation.speaker: Rodrigue
conversation.line: Is that so? That is too bad.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I believe he's in his quarters.

conversation.speaker: Rodrigue
conversation.line: Is that so? Thank you, Professor.

conversation.speaker: Rodrigue
conversation.line: I must ask him not to distract you, Professor, nor His Highness from the matter at hand.

conversation.speaker: Rodrigue
conversation.line: I am Rodrigue Achille Fraldarius. I bear the great honor of serving as a lord in the Kingdom of Faerghus. I have come in Margrave Gautier's stead to retrieve their stolen Relic. However... As I hear it, a group of students is to attend to this matter. I sincerely hope no harm comes to any of them.

conversation.speaker: Gatekeeper
conversation.line: Greetings, Professor! Nothing to report! Oh! Come to think of it, last month there was something to report, wasn't there? Thanks to you, I hear that everything was resolved. I never realized that bandits had entered... I'm not a great guard after all, am I? I hope you will forgive me one day.

battle.speaker: Sothis
battle.line: That form... Oh my. Is this your first time fighting such a thing? Then listen well to what I say.

battle.speaker: Edelgard
battle.line: Such is the fate of one whose life is corrupted by a Crest Stone... How pitiable. The least we can do is put an end to his suffering.

battle.speaker: Dimitri
battle.line: So, this is the power of a Hero's Relic. To create such a sinister beast... It has gone too far. I fear all we can do now is put an end to it.

battle.speaker: Claude
battle.line: How awful...So the Heroes' Relics are hiding such a terrible power within. I can't even tell friend from foe anymore. I feel for him, but...the best we can do now is finish this quickly.

battle.speaker: Sothis
battle.line: An evil power has caused them to grow quite large. Their life force is beyond a mortal like yourself. You cannot win unless you fell them twice or even thrice!

battle.speaker: Sothis
battle.line: Even if you've cornered one, you cannot let your guard down! Those things are even worse when threatened.

battle.speaker: Sothis
battle.line: Can you see that barrier? It is surrounded by great power. You must break through to fight that thing. A strong attack or gambit might help to break through more quickly. If you can break the barrier, that power will have nowhere else to go, and that will likely cause confusions for that thing. It cannot counter while confused, which means that is the best time to attack!

battle.speaker: Sothis
battle.line: If you break down all of their barriers, not only will they be confused, they will not be able to move for a short while. Without the power flowing around them, they will not be able to restore their barriers. You might even be able to get something from them.

battle.speaker: Sothis
battle.line: They have such might that they will not fear you alone. But a battalion could prove useful on that front... Attack them with a gambit to draw their attention and force them to target you.

battle.speaker: Sothis
battle.line: Be on your guard when they have realized their full power! The damaged caused at times like that is not contained to just one spot. Once they have charged some power ups, their barriers will be restored. You really must pay close attention to those things! Distract them with a gambit, or just take them down before they can attack. In any case, think carefully before you act!

battle.speaker: Sothis
battle.line: But you should be conquering that thing instead of talking to me! If you're out of questions, get over there and fight!

boss.speaker: Sylvain
boss.line: What is that? It's like watching a bad dream come to life.

cutscene.speaker: Miklan
cutscene.line: Not bad for your kind... A bunch of spoiled rotten children.

cutscene.speaker: Bandit
cutscene.line: Damn! Look at that... I'm outta here!

end.speaker: Gilbert
end.line: Goddess... The beast is gone, yet Miklan and the Lance remain.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: It is done. Let's retrieve the lance and depart at once.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: It's over... Let's retrieve the lance and leave this place.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: We defeated him, somehow... Let's grab the lance and return to the monastery.

end.speaker: Sylvain
end.line: Miklan...my brother...

end.speaker: Sothis
end.line: That man... His form was changed. It was as though that lance was swallowing him whole. Upon that sight, it makes sense that your students were upset. I wonder if those Relics truly hide such power? Yet even still, that power seems familiar. That form as well... As one who wields the Sword of the Creator... Does that mean you possess that power too?

end.speaker: Rhea
end.line: Professor, you have returned. The goddess is indeed generous with her divine protection. I have already heard Gilbert's report about what happened. See to it that you keep what transpired at the tower to yourself. People would lose faith in the nobles should rumors spread of one using a Relic and transforming into a monster. All regions of Fódlan would fall into chaos. We must avoid that at all costs. Please ensure the students who accompanied you understand that as well. Have I made myself clear?

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Yes, of course.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Hm...

end.speaker: Rhea
end.line: His transformation into a Black Beast was nothing short of divine punishment from the goddess. Punishment for someone arrogant and foolish enough to use a Hero's Relic even though they were unworthy and unqualified.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: You knew?

end.speaker: Rhea
end.line: Of course. That is why we rushed to recover it. Sadly, we did not arrive in time.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Will I share the same fate...

end.speaker: Rhea
end.line: If someone without a Crest were to wield the Relic you possess, they would likely meet the same fate as Miklan. You, however, have been chosen. You are worthy of wielding the Sword of the Creator, so there is no need to worry.

end.speaker: Rhea
end.line: The church will formally return the lance to House Gautier. If you would...

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: As you wish.

end.speaker: Rhea
end.line: You have my gratitude. I can see that I was right to trust you with this. Please report back. I will tell you of your new mission for the coming moon at that time.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: I will not.

end.speaker: Rhea
end.line: What is the meaning of this?

end.speaker: Sylvain
end.line: Ahem, excuse me.  Lady Rhea, I am overjoyed and beyond grateful to you for recovering the Relic of my family, House Gautier. Now, may I please have that lance? I have received direct approval from my father to take possession of it.

end.speaker: Rhea
end.line: As the next head of House Gautier, do you swear that you will never cause such a deplorable incident to transpire?

end.speaker: Sylvain
end.line: On my family's name...and on my brother's life, I swear it.

end.speaker: Rhea
end.line: Very well. However, I have one condition. You must never allow another to wield this lance. Your brother clearly demonstrated what fate awaits those who break that restriction.

end.speaker: Sylvain
end.line: Yes. I...I will not soon forget.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: I assume the archbishop was pleased with your performance. Did you return the Lance of Ruin?

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: I returned it.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: No need to lie, Professor. I saw Sylvain earlier. It was written all over his face.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: I did not return it.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: I'm glad. Sylvain must be overjoyed as well.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: There's no need to lie, Professor. No one could have expected you to disobey the archbishop.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: I keep thinking about what Gilbert told us...

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: About Miklan?

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: About House Gautier?

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: Yes, Miklan was discarded by his family because he was born without a Crest. Eventually he became a masterful thief and gathered enough ruffians to capture a fortress. Right or wrong, he was a gifted leader. He could have been a great asset to Fódlan. What a waste. It's true that a Crest can increase your magical abilities and allow you to wield the full might of a Hero's Relic. But one cannot measure a leader's worth based solely on whether or not they bear a Crest. There are plenty of talented people in this world without one.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: I completely agree.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Why is everyone obsessed with Crests?

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: People believe Crests are blessings from the goddess, that they're necessary to maintain order in Fódlan. But the people are wrong. Crests are to blame for this brutal, irrational world we live in. Their power is granted only to a select few, whom we elevate and allow to rule the world. Have you ever wondered if the only way to create a truly free world is to dispense with the goddess and the Crests? Do that, and people will have no choice but to rise and fall by their own merits.

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: Lady Edelgard. I question whether you revealed too much to the professor.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: Perhaps I did.

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: It is true that our teacher possesses a rare talent. Even I cannot deny it. The ability to wield the Sword of the Creator is concerning...

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: I've already explained this to you. My power alone is insufficient. That's why I'm borrowing power from those people. If our teacher can wield it in my stead... I believe that would be for the best.

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: It's a risk. A dangerous one. You leave me no choice but to take matters into my own hands. Please excuse me.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: I can't hide from the truth. I can't do all that I must on my own. If all I can rely on is my own ambition, my path won't be easy. Is it so risky...to reach out my hand? Father... I swear I will not stop until I succeed. My regret. My grief. My whole life. I've thrown it all away...into the darkness...

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: Is your meeting over, Professor?

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: You look troubled.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Are you weary?

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: I was just thinking about something. Professor... The possession of Relics and Crests has been highly valued in Faerghus since ancient times. It's far from uncommon for someone to lose their ability to lead their house because they don't bear a Crest. Just like Miklan. It happened to my uncle as well. The eldest child of the king, and yet he never ascended to the throne. All families whose bloodlines carry Crests of the 10 Elites are much the same. But House Gautier takes it a step further, and absolutely requires an heir who possesses a Crest.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Why are they so obsessed with it?

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Why House Gautier in particular?

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: To that house, the power of Crests is a necessity, not a luxury. House Gautier holds the most northern territory in the Kingdom, and they have fought with the people to the north for many years. The head of that house is responsible for protecting that territory from fearsome invaders, whom they keep at bay with the power of Crests and Relics. In exchange for that responsibility, they are granted special privileges within the Kingdom.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Their Crests grant them special privileges?

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: In a way. That said, ability cannot be measured by the possession of a Crest alone...

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Strength is strength, with or without a Crest.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: I believe the same. Ability cannot be measured by the possession of a Crest alone.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: I believe that Margrave Gautier was wrong to disinherit Miklan because he did not bear a Crest. Still, there is always a reason for why such customs stand the test of time. Imagine what this world would be like if no one placed any stock in Crests... Bloodlines that carry Crests would dwindle. The metaphorical blade used to oppose threats would eventually rest. This same argument has been made time and time again across the years. Both sides are at once right and wrong.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: What do you believe, Dimitri?

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: I believe those with Crests and those without should acknowledge the others' strengths and learn to respect each other based on personal merits. And that doesn't apply only to Crests. The same holds true for lineage, race, faith, ideologies... If we could just accept each other and make mutual concessions, one step at a time... Perhaps... Who knows if that's even possible. Everyone has something that is unacceptable within them. I certainly do, and I'd wager you do as well. I wonder which is best, Professor... To cut away that which is unacceptable, or to find a way to accept it anyway...

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Nice work, Teach. It's thanks to you that we successfully completed our mission. As for Miklan... I wonder if he really believed he could wield a Relic.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Hard to say.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: I bet he just wanted to get his hands on it, even though he knew he couldn't use it.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: I doubt it.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Agreed. He probably just wanted to get his hands on it, even though he knew it was futile.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Though I'm sure he wasn't counting on turning into a monster like that... I wonder if that monster represents another aspect of the Heroes' Relics. What a strange and terrifying power.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: I don't know.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: It seems so.

end.speaker: Tomas
end.line: Stories of misfortune have followed the Heroes' Relics since ancient times.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Tomas! You've caught me by surprise. That's not easy to do. Though I suppose I should've expected to see our librarian in his library.

end.speaker: Tomas
end.line: I am sorry to intrude. I simply heard you speaking of the Heroes' Relics. I can tell you more about them, if you'd like. The story goes that Nemesis was corrupted by evil because of the Sword of the Creator. Other Heroes also lost themselves by continuing to use the Relics...transforming into Black Beasts with twisted souls. There used to be a great many records regarding the dark history of the Relics.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Used to be?

end.speaker: Tomas
end.line: They have been destroyed, across all of Fódlan. Stripped from their shelves, including those that resided at this very library.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: You make it sound like the church is covering up the truth. But now that you mention it, Rhea was very specific about not wanting anyone to find out what happened at Conand Tower. Hey Tomas... why are you telling us all this?

end.speaker: Tomas
end.line: It seemed like you were searching for answers about the Relics. What is a librarian if not a guide in the search for knowledge. And not only have you been searching, but you have been doing so through the night. I would suggest you stop before the knights notice. And that is enough meddling for today. Please excuse me.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: So I've been found out, have I? I suppose I do spend more time at the library than most students. But I won't stop. I can't afford to.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: What are you after?

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Teach... You don't really expect me to tell you something so personal like that, do you? Though, I wouldn't mind sharing if you were to tell me some of your secrets in exchange...

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: I can't let this exchange pass without comment... If you're sharing secrets, perhaps I can share one as well?

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Are you sure you could survive that? I'd say you're the least likely to share secrets out of everyone at the academy.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: Heh heh, coming from you, I'll take that as a compliment. After all, you're easily the student with the most secrets.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: I'm afraid you overestimate me. My secrets don't amount to much. But back to Teach...

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: Don't try to change the subject, Claude. We're talking about secrets. Yours. Who is your father? And why did you appear so suddenly, as if from nowhere? Duke Riegan's eldest son died in an accident. Having tragically lost other family members as well, he was without an heir. The Alliance would undoubtedly have been shaken if House Riegan had lost its position of leadership. But then you showed up. Why did you return to House Riegan? What brought you to the monastery?

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: I would like to hear this as well.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: He doesn't have have to answer to you.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Alas...to be surrounded by women as lovely as flowers, only to be pricked by their thorns.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: My dream, in truth, is a selfless dream. But I require power to make it a reality. When I learned about the power of my Crest, I knew I had a chance. So I'm chasing that dream. To the bitter end, if need be. I came to this monastery because I thought I might find someone useful. Someone to help me on my path. So, what do you think? If you promise to help me achieve my dream no matter what, I'll promise to tell you anything.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: I have my own dream to tend to. I pray that yours does not interfere with mine.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: What about you, Teach?

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: If it's a noble dream...

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: That may be difficult.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: I see. Well, now isn't the time to discuss this. You are still my Teach, after all.

end.speaker: Rhea
end.line: Professor, you have done well to complete such a difficult task. You have shown exceptional skill in leading your students. I am forever grateful for the safe return of the Hero's Relic. Just as I expected, you have mastered the Sword of the Creator. Now then, I shall tell you about your mission for the coming month...

end.speaker: Seteth
end.line: Rhe– Archbishop!

end.speaker: Rhea
end.line: Seteth, what troubles you?

end.speaker: Seteth
end.line: Flayn is missing! I cannot find her anywhere!  Professor, have you seen Flayn recently?

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: I have not.

end.speaker: Seteth
end.line: I have searched everywhere! Where could she be?!

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Have you looked everywhere?

end.speaker: Seteth
end.line: I have searched every corner I can think of! I could not find her anywhere.

end.speaker: Seteth
end.line: She may be in danger! Oh no... No, no! What am I to do?!

end.speaker: Rhea
end.line: Calm yourself, Seteth. Professor, we shall continue our discussion another time.
